WHEN I received the news of your daughter Tul- lia's death, I was indeed as much grieved and dis· tressed as I was bound to be, and looked upon it as a calamity in which Ι shared. For if Ι had been at home, I should not have failed to be at your side, and should have made my sorrow plain to you face to face. That kind of consolation involves much distress and pain, because the relations and friends, whose part it is to offer it, are themselves overcome by an equal sorrow. They cannot attempt it without many tears‚ so that they seem to require consolation themselves rather than to be able to afford it to others.
